title-group.article-title: Geometrical approach-based defense-missile intercept guidance for aircraft protection against missile attack

abstract.p: This article develops a missile guidance technique for a ‘defense missile’ trying to protect a cooperative aircraft from guided munitions which have the same thrust and maneuvering capabilities as that of the defense missile. A novel guidance law for the missile-to-missile intercept is developed via a geometrical approach. Performance of the guidance law is analysed in detail and its potential is demonstrated with results from a six degrees-of-freedom simulation and comparison with a conventional guidance law.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Protecting an aircraft from missile attack is an essential doctrine to maintain primacy of the aerial force. Defensive maneuvers along with a decoy and/or electric counter measures can generally be pursued to avoid the threat from attacking missiles. However, aircraft motion/evasive maneuvers may be constrained due to load factor limitations or some mission goals, such as flying a specified route to attack some area, carrying a large antenna for reconnaissance, and so on. In such cases, steps to destroy the attacking missile will significantly enhance the aircraft protection capability and aerial supremacy. A ‘defense’ missile launched from the aircraft can provide protection against an attacking missile.

Missile defense against a guided missile is a challenging issue. Intercept guidance laws for a defense missile against a guided missile play an important role for the missile defense. Proportional navigation (PN) is a well-known guidance law for terminal intercept on general engagement and is widely used because of its simplicity on implementation [1]. The PN guidance law uses only the angular rate of the line-of-sight (LOS), and if available, the closing velocity between the missile and the target, otherwise, using the missile velocity. If there is no system time delay, acceleration limitation, and measurement noise for the missile and the target is moving with a constant velocity and bearing, the PN can guide a missile to achieve a perfect engagement, in other words, the zero-miss distance. The PN and its alternative representation as the zero-effort-miss guidance have been the basic for advanced guidance methodologies. For example, the augmented PN (APN) guides the missile with a compensation for the target’s the lateral constant acceleration [2]. Compensated PN guidance (CPNG) [3] (or velocity compensated PN guidance [4]) considers the missile’s axial acceleration component that affects the LOS rate which the basic PN tries to annul. The optimal guidance (OG) law results show that the PN is optimal in the sense that it is a minimum energy guidance law with a zero-miss distance against non-maneuvering targets for no-time-lag systems with a navigation constant of three [2]. Both the APN and the OG [5, 6] make allowances for the target maneuvers. Knowing the target maneuver bounds, the differential game theory (DGT) [7] or the sliding mode guidance [8, 9] can capture a maneuvering target without the need for precise target acceleration information. Recently, an integrated guidance and control approach has been developed to unify the guidance and control design process and to enhance the missile agility using various approaches, such as state-dependent Riccati equation (SDRE) [10], θ–D [11], sliding mode approach [8, 9], and so on. Most missile guidance algorithms are basically using the information about the missile and the target. Robb et al. [12–15] consider protecting an area by introducing the concept of ‘reachability’ and they applied this concept to an example of sea area defense. They introduce an ‘earliest intercept point’ and an ‘earliest intercept line’ (EIL) to analyse the possibility of risk area of concern and suggest that the guidance law should be formulated so that EIL is located outside the protected area.

In comparison, the objective of this article is to develop a scheme to protect with guided missiles a moving aircraft from attacking missiles. The EIL is used for a similar purpose in Boyell [16], wherein it is applied in a moving aircraft/torpedo engagement. Considering only the kinematics with the aid of the collision triangle, Boyell calculated a minimum range to intercept the attacking missile over a specified distance and obtained a closed form expression of the range for the missile to be successful against attacking missiles. Shneydor [17] developed conditions for the applicability of Boyell’s technique and simplified the expression for the operational range for the defense missile. But those analyses were based on an ideal guidance assuming a perfect collision course. Rusnak [18] applied DGT to such a three-player game; a protected aircraft, an attacking missile, and a defense missile by changing the three player games into a two-team game by way of grouping the same cooperative players: a protected aircraft and a defensive missile. Rusnak’s method demands the recursive backward computation from the end. Perelman et al. [19] further modified the Rusnak method to represent the two LOS rate terms in a closed form instead of using the recursive solution.

The proposed work here takes a basic approach to the three player guidance law like the PN in a way that it uses geometrical information of the moving object, that is, the protected aircraft’s LOS and the LOS rate. This type of guidance law can be classified as a three-point guidance [20–22] such as the beam rider (BR) guidance [2, 20–22] and the command to LOS (CLOS) guidance [2, 20–23]. The ‘three points’ in the three-point guidance usually means a missile, a target, and a reference point from which the target LOS is drawn or the target is observed. In this study, the protected aircraft is selected as one of the ‘three points’ instead of the reference point. The BR guidance is a guidance law to guide a missile in the centre of the beam which points to the target. The BR guidance is efficient when the target is stationary [20]. The system performance may, however, be degraded when applying an intercept against a moving target due to the beam direction changes which the BR-guided missile should follow. The CLOS guidance is a refined version of the BR guidance taking account of the LOS rate and its derivative. Ratnoo and Shima [23] applied the CLOS guidance for aircraft protection. The results show that the defense missile requires less lateral acceleration (latax) than those of the attacking missile. They also proposed a guidance law for the protected aircraft to provide maximum penalty for an evasive maneuver from the defense missile. Shima [24] proposed an OG methodology for a defense missile assuming prior knowledge of an attacking missile’s guidance law. Shaferman and Shima [25] applied a multiple model adaptive estimator algorithm with the multiple model adaptive control for such a three-player game to estimate the attacking missile’s guidance law. However, the problem is that as the range of the target becomes larger, the resolution of the target LOS angle at a tracking point will be lower. This fact degrades the system performance or demands a high-resolution radar to track a moving target from a distance. This is the reason why the three-point guidance is hardly applied in an aerial scenario.

This article proposes a different approach as compared to the BR or the CLOS guidance though it falls under the ‘three-point guidance’ classification. The proposed approach manipulates the geometry of the triangle formed by three vehicles. From here on, in order to avoid confusion, a protected aircraft and its cooperative (friendly) missile are called, a blue aircraft (BA) and a blue missile (BM), respectively, while an attacking missile is called a red missile (RM) or a target in the rest of this article. The underlying notion for this article is that in a three-point guidance, the BM can protect the BA from the RM attack if the BM is always located inside the line segment between the BA and the RM. In order to achieve this, we develop a ‘Triangle Intercept Guidance (TIG)’. The TIG is named after the triangle formed by the three vehicles’ geometry, that is, the BA, the BM, and the RM. The proposed method guides the BM such that one of the angles in the triangle is maximized to collapse the triangle to a line wherein the BM is to be located inside the line segment between the BA and the RM. The TIG law is found to exhibit low levels of latax as compared to the three point guidance in the midcourse phase and results in low miss distances as compared to the PN in the terminal phase of the engagement. The TIG law has benefits over the conventional three-point guidance law in two major aspects: (1) it results in a simple form which can handle the LOS angle error and its rate explicitly via using an exterior angle and its rate formed by the three vehicles (2) high sensitivity to the RM’s maneuvers in the proximity of the RM when the BM goes far from the BA, whereas low sensitivity to the RM’s maneuvers in the proximity of the BM where the conventional three-point guidance laws may fail. The rest of the article is organized as follows: section 2 describes the basic concept of the TIG law and the extension of the TIG to a three-dimensional (3D) space. In section 3, the potential of the TIG law is demonstrated by providing some simulation results and comparing them with that of the conventional PN guidance. Section 4 provides the conclusions from this study.

sec.title: 2.2 Development and analysis of the proposed guidance law
sec.p: This section describes the development of the TIG in 2D and the intuition it provided in developing a comprehensive 3D guidance law. First, the contribution of σ and σ· terms in equation (6) were analysed, through kinematical simulations. In the simulations, the BM uses the TIG law of equation (6) and the RM uses the PN guidance law to attack the BA. In these simulations, the velocities (250 m/s for the BA; 800 m/s for the BM and the RM) are assumed to be constant and the BM lateral accelerations are limited up to 50 × g.

Figures 4–6 show the simulation results. The labels, (a), (b), and (c) in these figures denote the results using the σ term only, the σ· (rate) term only, and both terms in the TIG guidance law of equation (6), respectively. Figure 4 shows the trajectories of the three vehicles in a 2D plane, along with the miss-distance values on top. The BA and the BM start from the origin while the RM is launched 20 km away from the BA with a 60° deviation from the BA heading in Fig. 4. As can be seen in Fig. 4, the BM trajectory with the TIG using either the σ term or the σ· term alone has a large curvature and results in a large miss distance (205 m for the former, 343 m for the latter). On the other hand, the TIG using both σ and σ· terms in equation (6) can capture the target with much less miss distance and its lateral acceleration history decays to zero with time as compared to the TIG using either the σ or σ· term only, as shown in Fig. 5. Furthermore, the exterior angle σ with the TIG converges to zero with time, whereas σ with the TIG using the either term only diverges at the end. It is observed that the acceleration command using either of the term alone goes to zero towards the end in Fig. 5(a) and (b) even though the angle σ does not go to zero in Fig. 6(a) and (b). What happens in this situation is that the closing velocity changes from positive to negative in sign before σ goes to zero and results in a large miss distance. This fact also implies that the miss distance cannot be reduced when using only σ or σ· term for the TIG guidance but the σ and σ·terms in the TIG law of equation (6) are important. Fig. 4

Another observation from these simulations is the oscillations in the commanded acceleration at the beginning (Fig. 5(c)). This is because BA’s proximity to the BM makes the LOSMA rate λ·MA rather sensitive to the BM motion, which in turn affects the σ·term in the TIG law. Command oscillations could be more conspicuous when the BM starts thrusting after the launch. To further verify this, a simulation with axial acceleration was conducted. Figure 7 shows the velocity profiles of the BM and the RM which are similar. Figure 8 shows the flight trajectories, along with the miss-distance values on top. The TIG law can still capture the RM with high accuracy. However, the higher magnitudes of fluctuations in the acceleration command are observed at the beginning of the engagement in Fig. 9, as expected. These oscillations might degrade the system performance and thus should be avoided. What cause these oscillations are the rapid changes of σ· at the beginning of the engagement as seen in Fig. 10. These rapid changes of σ· are due to the fact that the BM is launched from the BA and the LOSMA rate, λ·MA could change fast due to the BM motion (even if it is an axial acceleration) when the relative distance between the BA and the BM is small. sec.title: 3 6-DOF SIMULATION
sec.p:
Several series of simulations were made to demonstrate the potential of the proposed guidance law. The TIG was tested in a 6 degree-of-freedom (DOF) simulation with non-linear rigid body equations of motion of a missile model for the BM, and a 5 DOF model for the RM, and a 3 DOF model for the BA in the CADAC [3] environment. The 6 DOF and 5 DOF models utilize a short range air-to-air missile (SRAAM) models whose attitudes are controlled by acceleration autopilots in pitch and yaw, and roll control. Note that the 5 DOF model neglects the roll motion, or in other word, assumes perfect control of the roll motion as explained in Zipfel [3]. The SRAAM’s major parameters for the BM and the RM are summarized in Table 1. Further details can be found in Zipfel [3]. For comparison purposes, we also conducted simulations using two different sets of guidance schemes. One uses the PN guidance (PNG) for both mid-course and terminal guidance. The other set employs the CPNG for the terminal guidance, and the so called line-guidance (LG) for the mid-course guidance. As described at the introduction, the CPNG compensates the component of the axial acceleration normal to the LOS. The LG can be applied for the mid-course guidance methodologies and the LG uses the LOSTA as well as the LOSTM like the case of the TIG methodology. That is why the LG is used in this study for comparison purpose. Both CPNG and LG are discussed in Zipfel [3]. The RM uses the PN guidance along with a gravity-compensation term in these simulations. Two representative series of simulation results are discussed first to compare the characteristics of the TIG. Table 1

sec.title: 3.1 Simulations against a PN-guided RM (Case 1)
sec.p:
Figure 15 shows the trajectories of the BA, the BM and the RM. Figure 15(a) shows the results from the PNG, Fig. 15(b) presents the result using the LG for the mid course and the CPNG for the terminal guidance (LG/CPNG), and Fig. 15(c) shows the results with the TIG. The upper and lower figures in Fig. 15 show the flight trajectories of all the vehicles in the horizontal plane and the vertical plane, respectively. For ease in comparing the performance, the vertical axis range is zoomed for clarity to observe the trajectories of the RM and the BM. The dotted line in Fig. 15 indicates the BA’s flight path. (Note that the BA trajectory in the vertical plane is descending slightly because only a gravity compensation input is employed and no feedback control is applied to the BA to maintain the altitude.) The solid and broken lines in the figures showthe BM and the RM flight trajectories, respectively. The marker ‘+’ in each top figure indicates thepositions of the three vehicles at every 3 s andthese are connected by solid line so as to observe the three vehicles’ locations at the moments. (Note that the markers are omitted in the vertical plane figures due to invisibility of the vehicles’ trajectories.) It can be observed from Fig. 15, all guidance laws lead to successful intercepts. It can be seen from the upper figure in Fig. 15(c) that the TIG-guided BM changes its flight direction quickly at the very beginning after launch, and then the flight trajectory shows a curvature in response to the target maneuvers until the intercept so as to guide the BM to stay in the LOSTA whereas, from the upper figure in Fig. 15(a) and (b) is the BMs with the PNG and the LG/CPNG change their direction rather gradually after the launch. The PNG-guided BM trajectory also changes its direction slightly in response to the RM maneuver in the terminal phase and the LOSTM (not the LOSTA) seems maintain a constant direction after the initial phase but the BM does not stay in the LOSTA until the final engagement. The BM trajectory with the LG/CPNG forms a steep curve on the way to the intercept. It can also be seen in the vertical plane (lower figures in Figs 15(a) and (b)) that the BM with the PNG always changes its direction till the intercept and the BM with the LG/CPNG changes its direction sharply to the intercept point. Although the line BA–BM–RM is omitted in the vertical plane, it can be seen from the bottom figure in Fig. 15(c) that the TIG-guided BM can be located almost always inside the LOSTA. One of the great benefits for the BM to stay in the LOSTA is that the BM can also be used as a decoy by interrupting the RM‘s search/track of the BA. Therefore, the TIG has a potential to enhance the survivability of the BA using the missile not only as a counter-missile but also as a decoy. Fig. 15
BM’s trajectories along with a PN-guided RM in the horizontal plane (top) and in the vertical plane (bottom); (a) PNG, (b) LG/CPNG, and (c) TIG. (+: indicates the 3 vehicles’ positions in every 3 s)

The BM trajectory around the terminal engagements with the TIG shows much less curvature than the PNG and the LG/CPNG in both horizontal and vertical planes. This fact can be seen in acceleration time history in Fig. 16. Although the TIG-guided BM demands high lateral acceleration at the beginning after launch, the TIG requires less lateral acceleration after 4 s if compared to the other methods. The largeamount of the lateral acceleration used by the TIG at the beginning works for the swift heading error correction as can be seen in the flight trajectories in Fig. 15(c). It can be seen in Fig. 17 that the BM with the TIG heads towards the intercept point at an earlier stage and maintains the error angle at low levels until the final engagement whereas the error angles of the PNG or the LG/CPNG converge only gradually. Lesser amount of the lateral acceleration means savings in kinetic energy. The BM’s velocity histories are presented in Fig. 18. In contrast to the lateral acceleration time histories, the BM max velocity with the TIG at an early stage is lower than those with the PNG and the LG/CPNG because of the large lateral acceleration at the beginning after launch. However, the BM velocity with the TIG in a final stage is higher than those with the PNG and the LG/CPNG. In other words, the BM with the TIG can maintain higher kinetic energy than those with the PNG and with the LG/CPNG. Lateral acceleration is used for annulling the heading error at an early stage and consequently; this allows the BM to maintain higher kinetic energy at a later stage. Keeping the kinetic energy high is advantageous: first, conserving the kinetic energy allows the missile have a ‘larger reachability’. If the reachable distance is large, the BM can launch at an earlier stage where the RM is located much farther from the BA. Second, it reserves sufficient guidance force at the end of the engagement for higher maneuverability if needed. Fig. 16

Intercept time is an important feature for the missile defense since a quicker intercept implies that the BA’s proximity boundary for launch can be closer. All guidance laws capture the RM with small miss distances. Overall though, the TIG’s performance is the best. Table 3

sec.title: 3.2 Simulations against a PN-guided RM with spiral maneuver (Case 2)
sec.p:
Figures 19–21 show the BMs’ simulation results against a PN-guided RM with a spiral maneuver. Figure 19 shows the flight trajectories in the horizontal plane, whereas Fig. 20 shows the flight trajectories in the vertical plane. Similar to the previous case, the vertical axis range is zoomed for clarity in comparing the performances. These results suggest that the BM with the TIG is least affected by the RM’s weave (a fake) maneuver among the three methods. Similar trends can be noticed in the vertical plane as well in Fig. 20. The PNG guides the BM in a way that the trajectory is much winded in response to the RM maneuvers. Fig. 19
BM’s trajectories along with a spiral attacking RM in the horizontal plane; (a) PNG, (b) LG/CPNG, and (c) TIG Fig. 20
BM’s trajectories along with a spiral attacking RM in the vertical plane; (a) PNG, (b) LG/CPNG, and (c) TIG Fig. 21
BM’s acceleration histories along with spiral attacking RM; (a) PNG, (b) LG/CPNG, (c) TIG, and (d) PN-guided RM with spiral maneuver

Figure 21 shows the acceleration time histories of the RM with (a) the PNG, (b) the LG/CPNG, and (c) the TIG, and (d) the RM’s acceleration time history. The weaving maneuver for the RM starts around the 2.5 s after launch. All the methods are hardly affected initially by the RM’s weaving maneuver. Terminal phase results are different, however. Although the BM with the LG/CPNG is seen to be less affected by the RM’s weaving maneuver while utilizing the LG, once the guidance law is switched to the CPNG from the LG at around 6.6 s, the BM demands rather high accelerations, almost 10 × g, as seen at around 7 s in Fig. 21(b), whereas the other two methods demand less acceleration at the corresponding time. The PNG-guided BM demands over 10 × g at 9 s in Fig. 21 (a) as well as with the LG/CPNG in Fig. 21(b), whereas the BM with the TIG demands less amount in gravity as seen in Fig. 21(c). In contrast to the previous simulation results, the BM with TIG uses rather high lateral and normal accelerations towards the end of the engagement. This is in response to the RM’s fake maneuver in the final phase. Other methods in this case also exhibit high levels of accelerations at the end.

Table 4 shows the miss distances, the intercept times, and the BM’s final velocities in each method. The intercept times are almost the same. The resulting miss distance with the LG/CPNG is rather high as compared to those obtained by the other two methods. Taking account of this fact, it can be said that the TIG has the overall best performance. Table 4

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A novel geometry based guidance law for aerial defense was developed in this article. The proposed technique uses a protected vehicle’s information which makes the BM guidance scheme effective against the attacking missiles as compared to a PN-based conventional guidance law. From the view point of defending a moving aircraft, the proposed guidance law has excellent features on intercept as well as on concealment of the moving aircraft from missile attack.
